Model-based, real-time optimal control is an effective tool to improve the energy efficiency of central air-conditioning systems. However, its performance relies heavily on the accuracy of the system models, whereas the development of accurate models for central air-conditioning systems is not easy due to their complex dynamics and non-linearities. This study presents an adaptive regression model-based real-time optimal control strategy for central air-conditioning systems. In the proposed strategy, regression models are adopted to describe the relationship between the power consumption of the system and the variables that are optimised. Their simple structures enable a low computation load for model updating and real-time optimisation. The length of the training data (for model updating) is investigated, and a suitable length is found using a similarity check-based method. Case studies were carried out to assess the performance of the proposed strategy, and they demonstrated that (1) a week was the optimal length of the training data for the case system, (2) the proposed strategy saved energy use by 3.48–10.59% when compared with a benchmark system with no optimisation, and (3) the proposed method reduced the computational load by 85% when compared with a simplified physical model-based optimal control without adaptive modelling. Keywords Optimal control Data segmentation Adaptive model Energy saving Central air-conditioning system 1 Introduction Central air-conditioning (AC) systems contribute approximately 50% of the energy consumed by the building sector worldwide [1], which motivates the research and development of new technologies to reduce the energy use of these systems. As an efficient tool, real-time optimal control has been developed and practiced to reduce the energy use of AC systems’ operation. For example, Kusiak et al. [2] presented a data-driven optimisation using an ensemble technique for minimising the energy use of an AC system, and Ma and Wang [3] developed a supervisory optimisation strategy for central chiller plants using adaptive simplified models and a genetic algorithm (GA). Furthermore, Razmara et al. [4] developed a model predictive control (MPC) technique using an exergy model of a building, and Du et al. [5] presented a dual benchmark-based control perfect index (CPI) to judge the operation of an airport heating ventilation and air-conditioning (HVAC) system under different control strategies. More recently, Bianchini et al. [6] presented a specialised MPC technique to optimise AC systems and the storage devices under operational and thermal comfort constraints. Optimal control can reduce energy use by identifying optimal settings for the operation of AC systems and can be realised with or without the use of system models [7]. In the framework of model-based optimal control, system models are needed to describe the relationship between energy use and the decision variables that should be optimised [8]. The efficiency of model-based optimal control relies on the accuracy of system models, as demonstrated in [3,7], thus motivating many studies on AC modelling. In the current literature, AC models can be categorised into three types, namely, physical models, grey-box models, and black-box models [9], and as elaborated in [10], each has its own strengths and weaknesses. In AC optimal control, grey-box models are always adopted because (1) compared with physical models, the structural complexity of grey-box models is significantly reduced, thus reducing the computational cost to search optimal solutions, and (2) compared with black-box models, the parameters in grey-box models have certain physical significance, enabling their feasibility for (limited) extrapolation outside the range of training data covered. However, due to the non-linearities of AC processes, it is challenging to develop grey-box models for the optimal control of AC systems that can guarantee global accuracy, even when sufficient training data are available [10]. Therefore, this paper aims to solve the model problem using an adaptive strategy rather than exploring a new form of models. Adaptive modelling has been studied since the 1980s, and it has been widely used in non-linear process control. For instance, Dochain and Bastin [11] developed a non-linear adaptive control of non-linear bacterial growth systems; Slotine and Ydstie [12] presented an adaptive control approach using physical models for stabilising the continuous stirred tank reactor; and Luo and Billings [13] presented an algorithm that provides an adaptive modelling scheme using a polynomial, non-linear, autoregressive-moving average exogenous (ARMAX) model. Adaptive modelling has gained attention in AC processes, and a few studies can be found that focus on this literature. For example, Nassif et al. [14] developed a method to online tune the model parameters of an air-side cooling system using a GA to minimise the error between measured and estimated performance data. Moreover, Blum et al. [15] studied an adaptive model identification framework for MPC and showed that when a grey-box model was used for a building thermal envelope, the data of a few previous days would produce an accurate MPC-oriented model. However, these studies [14,15] were limited to the air-side and did not consider the dynamics of a whole AC process. There are two critical issues in the development of an adaptive modelling method for a whole AC process: one is the model selection, and the other is the selection of the length of training data for model updating. In adaptive modelling, suitable models should balance the model accuracy and the computational complexity of the online updating. Since adaptive modelling aims to find an accurate model for a period rather than a generalised global one, a simple model structure should be used rather than a complex one. Asad et al. investigated this issue in their study [16], where empirical-physical models were chosen and updated using a hybrid genetic algorithm (HGA) for a whole AC process. However, the empirical-physical models were found to have a converging problem because they involve iterations in their updating. Therefore, more suitable models for the whole AC process in this regard are necessary. Furthermore, the length of the training data for model updating is relative to the model accuracy. Since adaptive modelling does not target global accuracy, smaller training data lead to a more accurate model. However, if the training data are not long enough, then the updated model may be risky for real-time optimisation if the training data present a significant difference with the operation condition under which the system is optimised. For example, Blum et al. [15] found that the use of 1-day training data significantly reduced the accuracy of the models when the models were tested over a week. This is because the load condition for an AC system could be considerably different over two consecutive days. A suitable length of training data should thus be found for the adaptive modelling of a whole AC process. This paper presents an adaptive regression model-based real-time optimal control (ARMRTOC) strategy for a whole AC process with two major contributions: one is the use of regression models for the whole AC process because of their simple structures, which enable a low computation load for model updating and system optimisation, and the other is the systematic way of finding a suitable length of training data for model updating based on a similarity check. In addition, to further improve the model accuracy and to capture important characteristics of the performance, time-series segmentation of the training data was carried out, which resulted in a piecewise accurate performance model. To demonstrate the proposed strategy, a dynamic simulation platform was constructed for a complete AC system using a TRNSYS-MATLAB co-simulator. The operating conditions were generated separately from a validated TRNSYS model of real mega grade A, a 90-floor office building in Hong Kong. The proposed ARMRTOC strategy was tested under three weather seasons – spring, summer, and autumn – and its performance was compared with conventional control strategies. This paper is organised as follows. Section 2 explains the methodology for the proposed ARMRTOC strategy, which includes synthesis of data segmentation, regression model update, and system optimisation. Then, Section 3 illustrates the development of the regression models to be used for the synthesis of the ARMRTOC strategy, and Section 4 describes the analysis to determine the optimal length of training data for the regression model update. Finally, case studies are presented in Section 5, and the conclusion is provided in Section 6. 2 Adaptive regression model-based real-time optimal control 2.1 System description and conventional model-based real-time optimal control The AC system studied in this paper is illustrated in Fig. 1 . It is a typical centralised AC system with a bypass line, consisting of a condenser water loop, a chilled water primary loop, its secondary loop, and an air loop. The air loop takes heat from zones and transfers it to the water in the chilled water secondary loop inside the air handling unit (AHU) and then to the water in the chilled water primary loop. Afterward, the heat is transferred to the refrigerant inside the evaporator of the chiller and then to the condenser water inside the condenser. The heat will be ejected to the environment through the cooling tower. In this AC system, chillers, cooling towers, pumps, and fans are the main components that require power input. Many studies have demonstrated that under a given load or operating condition, the set points of the primary chilled water supply temperature ( T chws , 1 ), the cooling water supply temperature ( T cws ), and the supply air temperature ( T sa ) significantly affect the power consumption of the whole system [17,18]. Therefore, real-time optimal control is always formulated to minimise the total power of the whole system under a given load or operating condition by identifying the optimal values of these three set points (i.e. the decision variables for the optimal control) as shown in Eqs. (1) and (2): (1) T sa ∗ , T chws , 1 ∗ , T cws ∗ = arg min T sa , T c h ws , 1 , T cws P total Subject to current load condition and operation constraints, where T sa ∗ , T chws , 1 ∗ , a n d T cws ∗ are the optimal values of the decision variables T sa , T chws , 1 , a n d T cws , and P total is the total power of the whole system, which can be written as a function of the decision variables; that is, (2) P total = f T sa , T chws , 1 , T cws The function f ∙ can be considered as a general form of the performance models of an AC system, describing the relationship between the power consumption and the decision variables. In the current literature, f ∙ can be specified to have the form of physical models, grey-box models, and black-box models. The optimal values of the decision variables are found by solving Eqs. (1) and (2) at each optimisation time (normally every 30 min), and the optimised decision variables will be sent to the AC system to improve its performance. 2.2 Overview of the proposed real-time optimal control strategy The proposed ARMRTOC strategy uses the general formulation of the real-time optimal control in Eqs. (1) and (2). However, it integrates with an adaptive regression modelling scheme, as illustrated in Fig. 2 , where the performance models are updated regularly (e.g. at the beginning of each day) by a model-updating algorithm using the data inside a moving window [19]. The moving window is adopted to incorporate new data and drop out old data since old data, as illustrated in [15], are not desirable for the AC model for adapting to the recent changes in its operating condition. The moving window is illustrated in Fig. 3 , where each block represents a day of recorded data. The length of the window (i.e. k days) describes how old data remain in the window. When a new data block of d a y k + 1 is available, the window is augmented by the new data block of d a y k + 1 , and the oldest data block – day 1 in this case – is discarded. Offline trained models are initially used by the optimal control algorithm until the window is filled up to k days. Then, the models are updated every time the window slides to accumulate a new data block of day k + 1 . In Section 4, a suitable length of the training data will be found using a similarity-checking method. By observing that the cooling load of an AC system has a daily pattern – a low load phase, a transient increasing phase, a high load phase, and a decreasing transient phase – as depicted in Fig. 4 , a time-series segmentation of data in the moving window is carried out before they are used for the model update for further enhancing model accuracy. The time-series segmentation is designed to create a precise approximation of the time-series data by reducing their dimensions while capturing basic and important characteristics. As shown in Fig. 4, the segmentation of data is carried out in two steps. First, the window of the data is divided into N 24-hour segments. Then, every 24-hour segment is further divided into four sub-segments: (1) a low load phase, from midnight to 08:00; (2) an increasing transient phase, from 08:00 to 11:00; (3) a high load phase, from 11:00 to 21:00; and (4) a decreasing transient phase, from 21:00 to 24:00. The data in each segment are used to train the same performance models but lead to different model parameter sets, indicated as the model parameter set I to IV, as depicted in Fig. 4. When the optimisation is done at a different phase, the corresponding model parameter set should be chosen and used. Regression models are used because they can provide a computationally efficient solution for both online training and optimal control due to their simple structure [7]. For online training, the regression models can be formulated as an affine function (3) Y = ϕ × θ where Y is a vector, consisting of the measured outputs; ϕ is a matrix, consisting of measured states; and θ is a vector, consisting of all the parameters that need updating. The model update is done with a weighted least squares model identification method [20] presented in Eq. (4): (4) θ = Φ ' S Φ - 1 Φ ' S y where S is the weighting function. The criterion to minimise the Euclidean norm with respect to Φ becomes (5) ‖ ∊ ‖ 2 = ∑ i = 1 m s ii e i 2 where s ii denotes the training weight, which has decreasing positives values, assigning the highest value to the most recent data and the lowest value to the oldest data, and e i is the modelling error. 3 Regression model-based real-time optimal control 3.1 Regression model development Regression models are used in the proposed real-time optimal control strategy. Fig. 5 illustrates all the subsystems and the coupling between them in terms of input variables. The modelling of the AC system is divided into three major parts: (a) an air handling unit, (b) a chiller, and (c) a cooling tower. 3.1.1 AHU regression model According to a study by Cai et al. [21], the power P AH , f of the fan in the AHU is a function of the supply air mass flow rate m ̇ sa and the pressure rise across the fan. When a pressure-independent control is used to control the supply air pressure to be constant, the fan power P AH , f can be written as (6) P AH , f = α ah , 0 + α ah , 1 m ̇ sa + α ah , 2 m ̇ sa 2 where α ah , 0 , α ah , 1 , a n d α ah , 3 are model parameters. Given the AHU cooling load Q z , the enthalpy of the mixed air h ma and the enthalpy of the supply air h sa , m ̇ sa is calculated by (7) m ̇ sa = Q z h ma - h sa where h ma can be obtained according to the mixed air temperature T ma and humidity RH ma , and h sa can be calculated according to the supply air temperature T sa and the required humidity RH sa . Note that T sa is controlled inside the AHU by adjusting the chilled water flow rate. According to Velibeyoglu et al. [22], the chilled water return temperature T chwr , 2 is calculated by (8) T chwr , 2 = T chws , 1 + α ah , 3 + α ah , 4 m ̇ sa + α ah , 5 T ma - T sa where T chws , 1 is the set point for the secondary chilled water temperature, and a ah , 3 , a ah , 4 , a n d a ah , 5 are the model parameters. 3.1.2 Chiller regression model During the chiller operation, the components that need power input are the chilled water pump at the secondary side, the chilled water pump at the primary side, and the chiller compressor. The power of the chilled water pump at the secondary side is (9) P ch , p 2 = α ch , 0 + α ch , 1 m ̇ chw , 2 + α ch , 2 m ̇ chw , 2 2 where α ch , 0 , α ch , 1 , a n d α ch , 2 are the model parameters, and m ̇ chw , 2 is the chilled water mass flow rate at the secondary side, satisfying (10) m ̇ chw , 2 = Q z c w T chwr , 2 - T chws , 2 The power of the chilled water pump at the primary side is given by (11) P ch , p 1 = β ch , 0 + β ch , 1 m ̇ chw , 1 + β ch , 2 m ̇ chw , 1 2 where β ch , 0 , β ch , 1 , a n d β ch , 2 are the model parameters. As m ̇ chw , 1 is constant, P ch , p 1 is considered to be constant as well, which indicates that β ch , 0 , β ch , 1 , a n d β ch , 2 will not vary during the operation. The power of the compressor is given by (ASHRAE Handbook) [23] (12) P ch = α ch , 3 + α ch , 4 T cwr - T chws , 1 + α ch , 5 T cwr - T chws , 1 2 + α ch , 6 Q ch + α ch , 7 Q ch 2 + α ch , 8 T cwr - T chws , 1 Q ch where α ch , 3 , ⋯ , α ch , 8 are the model parameters, and Q ch is the cooling load of the chiller evaporation. By assuming that there is no heat loss during the transmission, and according to the law of energy conservation, Q ch satisfies (13) Q ch = Q z + P ch , p 2 + P ch , p 1 Similarly, the cooling load at the chiller condenser side satisfies Q ct = c w m ̇ cw T cwr - T cws , 2 = Q ch + P ch Therefore, T cwr satisfies (14) c w m ̇ cw T cwr - T cws , 2 = α ch , 3 + α ch , 4 T cwr - T chws , 1 + α ch , 5 T cwr - T chws , 1 2 + 1 + α ch , 6 Q ch + α ch , 7 Q ch 2 + α ch , 8 T cwr - T chws , 1 Q ch where T cws , 2 is given by the cooling tower model. 3.1.3 Cooling tower regression model In the cooling tower, T cws , 2 is given by (15) T cws , 2 = c w m ̇ ct , w T cws , 1 + P ct , p c w m ̇ ct , w where P ct , p is the power of the constant-speed pump, given by (16) P ct , p = β ct , 0 + β ct , 1 m ̇ ct , w + β ct , 2 m ̇ ct , w 2 where β ct , 0 , β ct , 1 , a n d β ct , 2 are the model parameters. As m ̇ ct , w is constant, P ct , p is constant as well, which indicates that β ct , 0 , β ct , 1 , a n d β ct , 2 should not vary during the pump operation. The cooling tower fan power is given by (17) P ct , f = α ct , 0 + α ct , 1 m ̇ ct , a + α ct , 2 m ̇ ct , a 2 where α ct , 0 , α ct , 1 , a n d α ct , 2 are the model parameters, and m ̇ ct , a is the mass flow rate of the air flowing out of the cooling tower. According to Ma and Wang’s work (2008), m ̇ ct , a can be predicted by (18) m ̇ ct , a = β ct , 3 Q ct β ct , 4 m ̇ ct , w β ct , 5 T cwr - T wb β ct , 6 where β ct , 3 , β ct , 4 , a n d β ct , 5 are the model parameters. Ma and Wang’s work [24] also demonstrated that these parameters are relatively stable and would not vary with a change in the operating condition. 3.1.4 Power calculation using the regression models Given the load Q z , the wet bulb temperature T awb and the constant flow rates m ̇ chw , 1 and m ̇ ct , w , with the measured T ma , RH ma , and assuming that the set points for the three loops T sa (as well as RH sa ), T chws , 1 , a n d T cws , 1 are defined, the total power of the whole system is calculated by Algorithm 1, as shown below: Algorithm 1 Calculate the total system power Step 1: Calculate m ̇ sa by Eq. (7) and P AH , f by Eq. (6). Step 2: Calculate P ch , p 1 by Eq. (11), T chwr , 2 by Eq. (8), and m ̇ chw , 2 by Eq. (10); then calculate P ch , p 2 by Eq. (9). Step 3: Calculate Q ch by Eq. (13), P ct , p by Eq. (16), T cws , 2 by Eq. (15), and T cwr by Eq. (14); then calculate P ch by Eq. (12). Step 4: Calculate m ̇ ct , a by Eq. (18), and then calculate P ct , f by Eq. (17). Step 5: Calculate the total power by P tot = P AH , f + P ch , p 1 + P ch , p 2 + P ch + P ct , f . In this algorithm, the parameters that require online updates are summarised in Table 1 . These parameters are identified using a weighted least squares method illustrated in Section 2.2. Vectorisation of the segmented data is carried out to further improve the computation time required for online parameter identification. The parameters that are identified offline are summarised in Table 2 . The parameter identification of these offline parameters was carried out using the genetic algorithms (GAs) method. The parameter identification was formulated as an optimisation task, where the objective was to minimise the modelling error. 3.2 Formulation of the real-time optimal control In the real-time optimisation, the decision variables at the current time instant ( t = k ) should be optimised under the current load condition Q z , k and the weather condition of T awb , k , where Q z , k = m ̇ ah , a , k h ma , k - h sa , k . Algorithm 1 indicates that for any defined set points for the three loops T sa ( RH sa ), T chws , 1 , and T cws , 1 , the total power can be estimated. Therefore, real-time optimisation is formulated as follows: T sa , k ∗ , T chws , 1 , k ∗ , T cws , 1 , k ∗ = arg min T sa , T c h ws , 1 , T cws , 1 P AH , f , k + P ch , p 1 , k + P ch , p 2 , k + P ch , k + P ct , p , k + P ct , f , k Note that both the chilled power pump at the primary side and the condenser water pump are constant speed pumps; they will not be affected by the variations of T sa , T chws , 1 , T chws , 2 , and T cws , 1 . Therefore, the optimisation can be simplified as (19) T sa , k ∗ , T chws , 1 , k ∗ , T cws , 1 , k ∗ = arg min T sa , T c h ws , 1 , T cws , 1 P AH , f , k + P ch , p 2 , k + P ch , k + P ct , f , k This optimisation is subject to the operational constraints given by (20) T _ cws , k ≤ T cws , k ≤ T ¯ cws , k (21) T _ chws , 1 , k ≤ T chws , 1 , k ≤ T ¯ chws , 1 , k (22) T _ sa , k ≤ T sa ≤ T ¯ sa , k Due to the non-linear nature of the models presented by Eqs. (6)–(18), finding an analytic solution to the problem in Eq. (19) is difficult. In this study, the hybrid genetic algorithms (HGAs) method was used to solve Eq. (19), the optimal set point for four local control loops. The HGAs method uses the GAs method’s rapid global search ability [25,16]. However, when it comes to a local search, GAs may struggle to converge and thus cannot ensure rapid optimisation time. Therefore, for the local search, a gradient-based optimisation method using a quasi-Newton algorithm [26,27] was used. The gradient-based optimisation method starts the search with the initial population from GAs, thereby ensuring faster and guaranteed convergence of the optimisation problem. To make this study complete, the pseudo-code for the proposed ARMRTOC strategy is presented in Appendix A. 4 Length of the training data The online training in this study does not aim to find a globally accurate performance model but a model that is accurate for optimisation in the next day. As illustrated in Fig. 6 a, where the cooling load profiles of 20 continuous days are given, the load profiles have large variations. On the one hand, if all of them are used to train the performance models, then the accuracy of the regression models might be reduced due to overfitting. On the other hand, if a short moving window is used, for example only one day, then there is a risk that the next day’s operating conditions might have a large difference. As an example, Fig. 6b shows the load profiles of two consecutive days, which are significantly different from each other. Thus, training using only 1-day operating data could not guarantee the accuracy of the models if the training data do not represent the next-day operating condition well. A criterion is needed for specifying the moving window length to maximise the similarity between the next-day operating data and the data in the moving window. To this end, it is necessary to carry out a similarity analysis between the n th day and the following (past) N days (batch size) and select the optimal length of data for updating the performance models. To find the past number of days with the most similarity to the given day, the dual tree wavelet transform (DTWT) with structure similarity (SSIM) is used, as illustrated in Fig. 7 . Six cases were analysed for N = 1 → 11 with Δ N = 2 , for all n = 1 → L - N with Δ n = 1 , where n is the number of iterations, and L is the total length of data used for the comparison, which was set to 30 days in this study. To perform the similarity analysis, a DTWT with SSIM is used as the similarity index because it can handle data with noise, missing samples, delays, and shift invariants [28]. The similarity between the global shapes of time-series data can be extracted by comparing its DTWT coefficients. The time-series data of two days to be compared can be represented by vectors (23) x 1 = x 1 , 1 , x 1 , 2 , ⋯ , r 1 , n 1 a n d x 2 = x 2 , 1 , x 2 , 2 , ⋯ , x 2 , n 1 where n 1 is the number of sampled data points of the cooling load across time axes with a sampling rate of 1 h. In the DTWT domain, the DTWT coefficients are denoted as d x 1 and d x 2 , extracted from one fixed decomposition level of expansion of data x 1 and x 2 . The SSIM evaluation in the DTWT domain is performed to obtain similarity index I . (24) I = D T W T - S S I M = 2 μ d x 1 μ d x 2 + K 1 2 σ d x 1 d x 2 + K 2 μ d x 1 2 + μ d x 2 2 + K 1 σ d x 1 2 + σ d x 2 2 + K 2 where μ d x 1 , μ d x 2 , σ d x 1 , σ d x 2 , and σ d x 1 d x 2 are the means, standard deviations, and cross covariances for DTWT coefficients d x 1 and d x 2 , and K 2 is a small positive value to avoid instability when the denominator is close to zero. The similarity index I is calculated between the n th day and each day in batch N in the first step (i). The expected value of I for each batch of comparison between the n th day and following (past) N days can be found by Eq. (25) in Step (ii). (25) I ' ⇒ E I = ∑ i = N I i p i Considering that each outcome is equiprobable, p i = 1 / N , that is simply the arithmetic mean of I i . Steps (i)–(ii) are repeated L - N times for each case by moving a day forward in each iteration, and the batch of I ' (expected value of I ) for each case accumulates in Step (iii). To further quantify the results for each case as the final step (iv), the arithmetic mean of the index I ' can be found using Eq. (26) and coined as the I-score, which can range from 0 to 1, with a higher score to signify the similarity. (26) I - s c o r e = I ' ¯ = ∑ i = 1 L - N I ' i / L - N 5 Case studies 5.1 Simulation platform A dynamic simulation platform of an AC system was built in TRNSYS [29] with the configuration shown in Fig. 1. This system had six water-cooled centrifugal chillers, each with a rated capacity of 7,230 kW. To reject the heat from the chiller condensers, 11 crossflow cooling towers were used, each with a rated flow rate of 250 l/s. Both the condenser water loop and the primary chilled water loop employed constant speed pumps, with rated flow rates of 410 l/s and 345 l/s, respectively. The secondary chilled water loop is used to deliver the chilled water to AHUs. The cooling load was generated from a mega grade A, 90-floor office building, which was located at the hub centre of Hong Kong. This building was also modelled in TRNSYS and validated in [30]. The system had four basic loops (shown in Fig. 1), including the condenser water loop, the primary chilled water loop, the secondary chilled water loop, and the supply air loop. Each loop was controlled by a PI controller to track its predefined set point. Here, the PI controller was simulated using Type 23. Furthermore, multiple chillers were used in this system, they were staged on or off according to measured cooling load during the operation, shown in Eq. (27). (27) N ch = c e i l Q ch / Q ch , c a p where c e i l ∙ is a function that rounds a number to the nearest largest integer; Q ch , c a p is the chiller rated capacity; Q ch , c a p = 7230 kW; and Q ch was the measured cooling load, given by (28) Q ch = c w m chw , 1 T chwr , 1 - T chws , 1 where m chw , 1 , T chws , 1 , and T chwr , 1 are the mass flow rate, the supply chilled water temperature, and the return chilled water temperature, respectively, at the primary side. Since the operation of the cooling towers was coupled with the chillers, the number of cooling towers was determined using Eq. (29), where coefficient γ depends on the chiller plant’s configuration. (29) N ct = γ N ch 5.2 Analysis for the length of training data The similarity index I ' for the cooling load of the summer month was found using Eqs. (24) and (25) for all six cases ( N = 1 → 11 with Δ N = 2 ), as presented in Fig. 8 . It can be clearly seen from Fig. 8a, b that the small batch size N = 1 , 3 can decrease the chances of having similar load profile, and training with a small batch of data will be risky. Moreover, increasing the batch size N = 5 , 7 in Fig. 8c, d improves the chances of having similar load profile significantly. However, too large a batch size N = 9 , 11 will not improve results any further, as can be seen in Fig. 8e, f where the performance is still consistent, but the index I ' starts to decrease slowly. In this comparison batch size, N = 7 provides the most consistent results with a higher index I ' . Note that both a consistent and a higher index I ' are important, since the preference is to have a reliable data size that will provide the consistency in the performance of the performance model, while a consistent and lower index I ' will provide consistency with a more generalised model that will reduce model accuracy. The similarity analysis for the months of spring and autumn were also carried out for all six cases using Eqs. (24) and (25), and the I-scores for the cooling loads of all three months were found using Eq. (26) and are presented in Fig. 9 . It can be clearly seen for all three months that batch size N = 7 (i.e. 1-week data) provides the higher I-score, which signifies the most similarity to the following day. Similarly, the wet bulb temperature was also analysed for similarity for data selection, since it is also an input to the regression model. Fig. 10 presents the I-scores for the wet bulb temperature of all three months. Again, batch size N = 7 provides the higher I - s c o r e s . Therefore, 7 days can be selected as an optimal length of data to carry out the performance model update. In the following sections, a new strategy to update the model parameters is proposed by considering the data segmentation based on the observations that (1) the similarity of weather or load condition in a period of 7 days will be the highest, and (2) during each working or weekend day, the load profile patterns are similar. 5.3 Accuracy of the performance model To evaluate the accuracy of the performance model, it was trained and used for prediction, online in real-time. The real-time data were continually filtered using a moving average filter and buffered. The size of the moving window used in this study was 1 week, while the frequency of the model updated was 1 day, and the sampling time of the simulation platform was 1 min. The online model training thus started when the window filled up and the data segmentation and vectorisation are were completed. The model training was done with a weighted least squares model identification method: Eq. (4), using the vectorised data (i.e. a piecewise representation of data in the moving window). The trained model was used to perform one-step-ahead predictions at each sample time. Since the frequency of the updated model was 1 day, the moving window was updated every day, and the performance model was periodically updated using the processed data. The resulting estimates of the power consumption of the chiller plants, AHUs, and cooling towers, as well as the secondary chilled water return temperature, were recorded in real-time for one more week (after the first week when the moving window filled up) and compared with the actual measurements, which are presented in Fig. 11 . It can be seen that there is a good agreement between the estimates from the performance model and the actual data. To quantify the accuracy, two performance criteria were used: root-mean-square error (RMSE)/mean-square error (MSE) and the coefficient of determination ( R 2 ), as shown in Eqs. (30) and (31). It should be noted that the initial 7 days are not considered here. The RMSE and R 2 values are listed in Table 3 . The RMSE/MSEs are small, and the R 2 values are close to 1, indicating high accuracy of the performance model. (30) R 2 = 1 - ∑ y i - y ^ 2 ∑ y i - y ¯ 2 where y i is the actual value, y ^ is the estimated value, and (31) y ¯ = 1 n ∑ i = 1 n y i 5.4 Performance evaluation of the ARMRTOC strategy and discussion The overall performance of the ARMRTOC strategy was evaluated based on energy consumption and computational load. To examine the energy performance of the proposed strategy, it was tested under three weather seasons: spring, summer, and autumn. The ambient conditions for a month in spring (April), summer (July), and autumn (September) from the selected building model (i.e. mega grade A building [30]) were used in this regard. The cooling load profiles of these three months, along with dry bulb and wet bulb temperatures, are presented in Fig. 12 . The performance bounds and thresholds used in the operational constraints of Eqs. (20)–(22) are listed in Table 4 . The optimisation problem in Eq. (19), subject to the system performance model Eqs. (6)–(18) and operational constraints Eqs. (20)–(22), was solved using the HGAs method. Moreover, the frequency used to carry out system optimisation was 1 h. For benchmarking purposes, the energy performance of the proposed ARMRTOC strategy was compared with the conventional fixed set point strategy and the conventional model-based real-time optimal control (MRTOC) strategy using a simplified physical model [31]. The settings for the fixed set point strategy for three seasons are listed in Table 5 , and Fig. 13 a illustrates the total power consumption of three strategies for July (summer). The conventional fixed set point strategy provided 2455891.665 kWh of energy consumption; the MRTOC strategy provided 2248136.26 kWh of energy consumption; and the proposed ARMRTOC strategy provided the most energy-efficient performance, with 2195714.253 kWh of energy consumption. Likewise, total power consumption for April (spring) and September (autumn) for the three strategies is presented in Fig. 13b and Fig. 13c, and the analysis of the energy consumption of these strategies with potential energy savings is presented in Table 6 . It can be seen that the proposed ARMRTOC strategy can reduce energy consumption significantly. The energy consumption for April (spring) was reduced by 3.48% compared with the fixed set point and by 1.61% compared with the MRTOC strategy. The month of July (summer) experienced a reduction in energy consumption by 10.59% compared with the fixed set point and by 2.33% compared with the MRTOC strategy, and for September (Autumn) energy consumption was reduced by 5.94% compared with the fixed set point and by 1.96% compared with the MRTO control strategy. To judge the computational load performance, the proposed ARMRTOC strategy was compared with the conventional MRTOC strategy with a simplified physical model [31]. The time required to carry out system optimisation was measured by calculating the search time required by the ARMRTOC and MRTOC strategies. The time needed to perform the model update was measured by calculating the search time required by the ARMRTOC strategy to search unknown model parameters. Fig. 14 presents the computational load for both strategies, where the online training time for the ARMRTOC strategy is highlighted in red. The proposed ARMRTOC strategy provided a much more computationally efficient performance compared to the MRTOC strategy. The ARMRTOC strategy needed 4.0684 s and 44.5998 s for online training ( t r ) and system optimization ( t o ), respectively. In contrast, the MRTOC strategy needed 344.3478 s for system optimisation ( t o ). The selection of a regression model for the ARMRTOC strategy lead to faster system optimisation, and together with the vectorisation of data, the online training of the model was also fast. The proposed ARMRTOC strategy provided an 85% reduction in computational load. The ARMRTOC strategy was tested for both accuracy and energy performance under variable load conditions in three weather seasons that included weekends (to demonstrate part-load performance), and it was able to capture and adapt to varying load conditions. Overall, the proposed ARMRTOC strategy provides reliability in decision making with manageable computational load, leading to optimal system operation and a reduction in energy use. However, one inherent problem with this strategy is that it relies on online data streaming (i.e. sensor-based measurements). In reality, sensor-based measurements are associated with measurement uncertainty, and the measurement uncertainty can reduce the performance of the ARMRTOC strategy. In the next phase of work, the measurement uncertainty associated with sensor-based measurements will be studied and quantified, and their influence on the ARMRTOC strategy will be analysed. Furthermore, a data fusion technique will be integrated into the ARMRTOC strategy to enhance its robustness. 6 Conclusion This paper presented a new adaptive regression model-based real-time optimal control strategy for complex air conditioning systems. To improve the accuracy of the performance model, the online parameter adaptation was implemented. This strategy used a regression model of the AC system, and due to the simple structure of the performance model, it was computationally efficient for both model updates and system optimisation. To capture important characteristics from data, time-series segmentation was performed, and data selection was implemented through a moving window approach to adapt to changes. The suitable length of the moving window or training data was found in a systematic manner through a similarity analysis of recorded data. Moreover, vectorisation of data was carried out before the model update to reduce the online computation time. The case study was conducted with a typical large-scale complex AC system, and a week of recorded data was found to be the most suitable length of the training data for carrying out the frequent model update. The results demonstrate that the adaptive regression model-based real-time optimal control strategy can reduce an AC system’s energy consumption by 10.59% and its computational load by 85%. Thus, the proposed method might find potential application in real buildings. Due to the limitation of the experimental testbed, the proposed strategy was only evaluated on a simulation platform. Future work will focus on the experimental validation of the proposed strategy. Appendix A Algorithm Pseudo-code for proposed ARMRTOC 1. Initialisation: Perform the following steps: Input – Repeat at every sample time instant (i.e. 1 min). 1.1. Read and record the current operating condition x n of the system, which includes both system state and ambient condition. 1.2. Based on load demand, compute the number of operating chillers N ch and cooling towers N ct by Eqs. (27) and (29). 1.3. Use offline parameter α until the data window fills up. The window size was 1 week. 2. Data processing: Perform four-stage data processing. Repeat Steps 2.1–2.4 periodically at 00:00: 2.1. Filtration – Filter recorded data using moving average (low pass) filter. 2.2. Data selection – Update the moving window at 00:00, adding a new 24-hour data block and omitting the oldest 24-hour data block. 2.3. Time-series segmentation – Segment the updated data window into 24-hour segments; then, divide each day into another four segments: (1) a low load phase, (2) an increasing transient phase, (3) a high load phase, and (4) a decreasing the transient phase. 2.4. Vectorisation – Solve the non-linear terms of Eqs. (6), (9), (12), and (17), and arrange the data as vectors or matrices. 3. Performance model update: Repeat periodically every 24 h. 3.1. Solve Eqs. (4) and (5) to update the performance model θ ∗ . 4. Optimisation: Repeat the following steps periodically every 1 h: 4.1. Find a solution to Eq. (19) s.t. constraints defined in Eqs. (20)–(22) based on the performance model Eqs. (6)–(18) 4.2. Output – Update the set points d ∗ = T sa , k ∗ , T chws , 1 , k ∗ , T cws , 1 , k ∗ to the local-loop controllers. References [1] IEO. coredata.dc:description: Model-based, real-time optimal control is an effective tool to improve the energy efficiency of central air-conditioning systems. However, its performance relies heavily on the accuracy of the system models, whereas the development of accurate models for central air-conditioning systems is not easy due to their complex dynamics and non-linearities. This study presents an adaptive regression model-based real-time optimal control strategy for central air-conditioning systems. In the proposed strategy, regression models are adopted to describe the relationship between the power consumption of the system and the variables that are optimised. Their simple structures enable a low computation load for model updating and real-time optimisation. The length of the training data (for model updating) is investigated, and a suitable length is found using a similarity check-based method. Case studies were carried out to assess the performance of the proposed strategy, and they demonstrated that (1) a week was the optimal length of the training data for the case system, (2) the proposed strategy saved energy use by 3.48–10.59% when compared with a benchmark system with no optimisation, and (3) the proposed method reduced the computational load by 85% when compared with a simplified physical model-based optimal control without adaptive modelling.
coredata.dc:title: Adaptive regression model-based real-time optimal control of central air-conditioning systems
